questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the case in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive imaging technique that is highly effective for visualizing the biliary and pancreatic ducts, including the detection of choledocholithiasis, which is the presence of stones in the bile duct. MRCP has largely replaced ERCP as the diagnostic gold standard for choledocholithiasis due to its similar sensitivity (90-94%) and specificity (95-99%), without the risks associated with ionizing radiation, intravenous contrast, or the complications inherent in ERCP.

MRCP provides clear images that can help identify the number, size, and location of bile duct stones. It's particularly useful when strong or moderate signs of common bile duct stones are present.

KEY TAKEAWAY- MRCP is recommended for patients with symptoms suggestive of biliary obstruction, such as jaundice or pancreatitis, and when there is a need to evaluate the anatomy of the biliary tree preoperatively. It's also used when ultrasound and CT findings are inconclusive or when there's a high clinical suspicion of choledocholithiasis.

Reference:

Choledocholithiasis | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/choledocholithiasis.

choices.text: Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and cystic lesions in the Breast
Can be used for mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of USG over Mammography?
questions.solution:
While ultrasound (USG) has several advantages over mammography, such as being particularly useful in young females with dense breasts and differentiating between solid and cystic lesions, it is not typically used for mammographically undetectable, clinically non-palpable breast masses. Mammography remains the gold standard for the initial evaluation of non-palpable breast masses. Ultrasound may be used as a complementary tool alongside mammography for further evaluation.

Reference:

(1) Breast Ultrasound vs. Mammography: Which Is Best? - Verywell Health. https://www.verywellhealth.com/why-not-annual-ultrasounds-instead-of-mammograms-430185.

(2) Which Is Better? Breast Ultrasound or Mammogram? - MedicineNet. https://www.medicinenet.com/is_a_breast_ultrasound_or_mammogram_better/article.htm.

(3) Mammography vs Ultrasound: Breast Cancer Screening Options. https://www.bedfordbreastcenter.com/blog/breast-ultrasound-vs-mammography/.

(4) Breast Ultrasound Vs Mammogram: What Are The Differences? https://www.health365.sg/breast-ultrasound-vs-mammogram/.

questions.text: Identify the fracture seen in x ray shown below.
questions.solution:
There is evidence of displaced fracture of left 5th and 6th rib on posterior aspect.

Imaging techniques for diagnosing rib fractures typically include:

Posterior ribs are horizontal while anterior ribs are vertical.

  • Plain Radiography (X-ray): This is often the first imaging modality used. However, it may miss up to 50% of rib fractures even with dedicated oblique rib projections.
  • Ultrasound: It is more sensitive and specific than conventional radiography for rib fracture detection in blunt trauma when performed by a trained clinician. It can also detect radiographically occult costal cartilage fractures and assess the underlying lung for associated traumatic pathology.
  • Computed Tomography (CT) Scan: A definitive diagnosis of rib fractures can be made with a CT scan. Advanced imaging like CT is often not necessary for isolated (one or two ribs) fractures once associated injury has been adequately excluded, typically with a chest radiograph.

These imaging methods help in the accurate diagnosis and management of rib fractures, ensuring proper treatment and monitoring for any potential complications.

Reference:

Rib fractures | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/rib-fractures.

choices.text: Increase in cartilaginous cap thickness > 2 cm on MRI
Bone marrow continuity in the tumor and parent bone seen on x-ray and CT
Cases to grow beyond skeletal maturity/new onset pain

questions.text: A young patient has swelling above the knee for the past few years. He complains the swelling has suddenly increased in size. Radiograph of the knee is shown below. Which of the following is a sign of malignant transformation of the lesion shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
Osteochondroma(exostosis) is a bony outgrowth with a cartilaginous cap,this cartilaginous cap has risk of malignant transformation i.e Chondrosarcoma. This cap is seen on Mri not on xray.It is the most common type of benign bone tumor.

B) Growth towards the joint: This is also not a definitive sign of malignancy. Osteochondromas typically grow away from the joint.

C) Bone marrow continuity in the tumor and parent bone seen on x-ray and CT: This is a characteristic feature of osteochondroma. It indicates that the tumor is connected to the underlying bone and is not a separate entity.

D) Cases to grow beyond skeletal maturity/new onset pain: This is not a typical feature of osteochondroma. Osteochondromas usually stop growing when the bone stops growing.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality found in the ultrasound image shown below.
questions.solution:
The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder. In terms of anatomy, it refers to a folding of the fundus of the gallbladder back upon the body, giving it a distinctive 'cap-like appearance'.

Significance-wise, the Phrygian cap is generally considered to be a normal variant with no pathological significance. It is asymptomatic and does not require any treatment. However, it's important to recognize this variant in imaging studies because it can sometimes be mistaken for a pathological condition. For instance, it may simulate a mass in the liver during hepatobiliary imaging, but it is not associated with any disease and typically does not cause symptoms.

In clinical practice, awareness of the Phrygian cap is significant primarily to prevent misdiagnosis and unnecessary surgical intervention, such as cholecystectomy, unless there are other indications for surgery like biliary colic or cholecystitis.

Reference:

(1) Phrygian cap | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/phrygian-cap.

questions.text: Banana sign on usg associated with which of the following conditions.
questions.solution:
"Banana sign" in an ultrasound refers to an abnormal curvature of the cerebellum resembling a banana. This sign is typically associated with conditions such as Chiari II malformation and/or spina bifida. It is visible on axial imaging through the posterior fossa of fetuses and indicates that the cerebellum is flattened, inferiorly displaced, and wraps around the brainstem.

There is frequently concurrent hydrocephalus. The same condition also gives rise to the "lemon sign," which refers to the typical frontal "pinching" of the calvarium giving a "lemon" appearance of the skull.

Reference:

Banana sign (cerebellum) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/banana-sign-cerebellum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with mild fever and right upper quadrant pain and bloody diarrhea for past 7 days. On ultrasound, there is a hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders in the posterosuperior aspect of the right lobe of the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, right upper quadrant pain, and bloody diarrhea are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.

Ultrasound findings: A hypoechoic lesion with irregular borders is a typical ultrasound appearance of a liver abscess.

Amoebic liver abscess: This is caused by the parasite Entamoeba histolytica and is more common in areas where sanitation is poor. It can present with similar symptoms, but the ultrasound appearance may be different double rim sign seen.It occurs mostly in young patients.

Pyogenic liver abscess: This is caused by bacterial infection and is more common in immunocompromised individuals. Pt will be more toxic. usg will show cluster sign.it occurs mostly in elderly patients.

Hydatid cyst: This is caused by the parasite Echinococcus granulosus and is more common in areas where there is close contact with dogs. It can present with similar symptoms, but the ultrasound appearance is usually different.

choices.text: X-ray is the Investigation of Choice.

questions.text: Which is a correct statement regarding thymoma?
questions.solution:
Thymoma is anterior mediastinal mass.

Other Anterior mediastinal mass

Teratoma, Terrible Lymphoma, Thyroid (ectopic)

Middle mediastinum mass- vascular or bronchogenic lesion like cyst.

Posterior mediastinal masses are neurogenic masses.

A. X-ray is Investigation of Choice: It is a false statement .

For anterior mediastinum masses CECT is the investigation of choice. While posterior mediastinal masses are neurogenic for which MRI is investigation of choice.

B. MC location is posterior mediastinum: This is incorrect. Thymomas typically arise in the anterior mediastinum, located behind the sternum.

C. Clinically presents with dysphagia: This is incorrect, dysphagia usually presents with posterior mediastinal masses not anterior.

D. MC Neoplasm of Thymus: This is correct. Thymoma is the most common primary neoplasm of the thymus.

questions.text: A middle aged patient with lumbar pain, pyuria and fatigue. Plain X-Ray Abdomen is shown below. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Medullary nephrocalcinosis is a condition where calcium salts are deposited in the medulla of the kidneys. This can lead to kidney stones and damage the kidneys over time.

Causes:

  • Hyperparathyroidism- Medullary nephrocalcinosis occur mc common in pt of hyperparathyroidism. Parathyroid adenoma is an important cause of hyperparathyroidism.
  • Medullary sponge kidney
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Hypervitaminosis D
  • Milk-alkali syndrome
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 9yr old girl has brown skin rashes on chest, multiple bone lesions and fractures which show increased uptake on bone scan and endocrine thyroid abnormalities, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Shepherd crook deformity with ground-glass lesion is fibrous dysplasia . More osteoblastic activity is seen as the reason why there is increased uptake on bone scan.

Mccune albright syndrome- Triad of :

Precocious puberty

Cafe au lait spots

Fibrous dysplasia

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Cafe au lait spots in McCune albright syndrome is irregular (coast of maine).
  • Cafe au lait spots in in Neurofibromatosis is uniform (coast of California)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who sustained a shoulder injury presented with swelling of shoulder. X-ray is shown below, which is/are the ligament injured?
questions.solution:
Normally the inferior aspect of acromion is in continuation with the inferior aspect of clavicle .

In the given image, the inferior aspect of clavicle is not in continuation with the inferior aspect of clavicle suggestive of acromioclavicular dislocation.

  • AC ligament: ruptured
  • CC ligament: ruptured
  • joint capsule: ruptured
  • deltoid muscle: detached.
  • trapezius muscle: detached

The above findings suggest type III Rockwood classification.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/cases/Rockwood classification of acromioclavicular joint.# image-51762506.
